subject: RE: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: I agree.  Unit test metrics can be a great morale booster ( Look how many test we wrote this week! ) or a relatively minor and unreliable indicator of
messageBody:
I agree. Unit test metrics can be a great morale booster ("Look how many
test we wrote this week!") or a relatively minor and unreliable indicator of
development progress ("0 unit tests so far" tells you something, but really
high numbers don't necessarily say a lot). Code coverage is the most
scientific instrument for determining test thoroughness. Confidence should
be based a lot on code coverage, and a lot on use case requirements being
met and tested.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

> and the opposite:
>
> public void testReallyHard () {
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> assertTrue(true);
> }
>
> 1 test and 10 assertions... great isn't it?
>
> The point is: you can always give a false sense of security.
> Counting the # of asserts is not the holy graal.
>
> I think that code coverage is a far better solution.
>
> -Vladimir
